content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple (approximately 8-10) discrete fragments of tissue against a white background. These fragments vary in size and staining characteristics. Some are predominantly pink and appear to be fibro-adipose tissue, while others contain dense, dark purple (basophilic) areas. These basophilic areas are highly suggestive of lymphoid tissue, indicating that these are likely lymph nodes. This is a typical presentation of a lymph node dissection submitted for staging of a colorectal carcinoma.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, the primary task is to identify every lymph node on the slide and meticulously examine it for evidence of metastatic cancer. The area highlighted by the green box is one of the tissue fragments that clearly contains a dense, basophilic cellular component, which is characteristic of a lymph node. It is imperative to zoom into every such area to assess the cellular architecture at high magnification to determine if the node is benign (reactive) or malignant (contains metastatic tumor cells). I am systematically reviewing each potential lymph node, and this is one of the central fragments on the slide. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because this particular tissue fragment (one of the central nodes) exhibits a prominent dark purple, hypercellular region that stands out against the paler, fatty background. At low power, such a finding is highly suspicious for a metastatic tumor deposit replacing the normal lymph node architecture. The purpose of zooming in is to closely examine the morphology of the cells in this dense infiltrate to confirm whether they are malignant epithelial cells (i.e., metastatic adenocarcinoma) or a reactive or neoplastic lymphoid process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every piece of tissue on the slide to identify all lymph nodes and search for evidence of metastasis. The selected area in the green box corresponds to one of the smaller, discrete tissue fragments in the upper right quadrant. Its intensely dark purple (basophilic) and densely cellular appearance at low magnification is highly conspicuous and requires immediate high-power examination. This appearance could represent a lymph node completely replaced by tumor, a highly reactive lymph node, or another type of cellular process. It is crucial to zoom in to differentiate these possibilities. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a fragment of a lymph node embedded in fibro-adipose tissue. The architecture of the node is partially visible. There are distinct, dense aggregates of dark purple cells, which, upon closer inspection, appear to be mature lymphocytes. These aggregates resemble lymphoid follicles. I do not see any clear evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic epithelial cells, or extensive necrosis. There is some surrounding hemorrhage (red blood cells) and fibrous tissue. My impression of this specific field is that it shows a reactive lymph node, which appears negative for metastasis. However, a definitive conclusion would require careful examination of the entire node and possibly other serial sections or immunohistochemical stains.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the tissue is composed of numerous mature fat cells (adipocytes), indicating significant fatty infiltration of the lymph node. Interspersed between the fat cells is a dense, diffuse infiltrate of monotonous, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei. These cells strongly resemble a population of mature lymphocytes. There are no clear signs of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as glandular formation, large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or significant necrosis. My impression is that this is a lymph node negative for metastatic carcinoma, but it shows extensive fatty replacement and is densely infiltrated by small lymphocytes, which could represent chronic lymphadenitis or potentially a low-grade lymphoproliferative disorder like CLL/SLL, which would be an incidental finding.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, dark, round cells with scant cytoplasm, consistent with lymphocytes. This infiltrate is expanding and effacing the underlying parenchyma. The background tissue architecture, with its empty, circular spaces, is highly suggestive of lung alveoli rather than a lymph node sinusoids. I do not see the characteristic features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as atypical gland formation, large pleomorphic cells, or desmoplasia. My impression is that this is a section of lung tissue with a dense lymphoid infiltrate, which is negative for metastatic carcinoma. This tissue fragment does not appear to be a metastatic lymph node.
